THE NEWS ',ETTER
VOL. XV, No. 28.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 15, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

CHANGE IN MEDICAL SCHOOL

ATHLETIC BOARD NOMINATIONS

LACROSSE CHAMPIONSHIP

VIRGINIA OUTCLASSED

Department Heads Will Be Paid Larger
Salaries and Will Give Up
Private Practices.

Annual Meeting of General Athletic
Association Held Last Monday in
Hopkins Hall-Election Today.

A Remarkable Lacrosse Season Closes
Without a Defeat for Black and
Blue -Hopkins 9, Stevens 3.

The Hopkins Track and Field Men Exceed Most Sanguine ExpectationsHopkins 62 1-3, Virginia 41 2-3.

For the past week there has
been a great •deal of discussion in
the newspapers and elsewhere of
the change which it is proposed to
make in the policy of permitting
professors at the Medical School to
devote a large amount of their time
to their private practices. By the
new method, larger salaries will be
paid and the doctors will be permited to have private surgical and medical practice only at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The change has been agitated
ever since Dr.J.Whitridge Williams
received the deanship in January,
and it is well known that when Dr.
Howell resigned and Dr. Williams
was elected, there was an • understanding that the latter should be
free to agitate for the change, which
he favors very much. So far, nothing definite has been done, but Dr.
Williams has stated that the discussions in the Medical Faculty
have shown that the professors
unanimously favor the plan and that
a recommendation urging its adoption will probably be made to the
board of trustees.
Dr., Williams estimates that only
five or six department heads will
be affected at first, and then the
severance will be made to apply to
the men directly under them. He
does not think that the change will
be followed by any, resignations,
as he says that it will be inaugurated only if it is thought best for
Hopkins and that all of the professors have the welfare of the institution at heart and are willing to do
everything in their power to increase its efficiency.
What part Dr. Abraham Flexner
had in proposing the change has
also been much discussed. During
February, he was in Baltimore for
over a week, attending, while he
was here, the Commemoration exercises and discussing medical education with his professorial frier0s.
While he was here, also, the first
public announcement of the change
was made at the alumni dinner,
February 22, when Dr. Williams
acted as toastmaster. It was stated
Saturday, however, that although
Dr. Flexner fully approves of the
plan, it was agitated at Hopkins
before he ever came down here, and
that his advocacy is that of a private individual and not as the
head of the Medical Department
of the Carnegie Fund for the Advancement of Teaching. It is not
believed that the advocacy of Dr.
Flexner will. cause Mr. Carnegie
to loosen up for the money.

In accordance with the constitution of the Johns Hopkins Athletic
Association, the annual meeting for
the nominations of the officers and
delegates to the Board of Governors
of the General Athletic Association
was held last Monday in Hopkins
Hall. The election will be held
today at 5 P. M. in the same place.
Dr. Radcliffe, whose term as
alumni delegate has expired, was
unanimously renominated. Jimmie
Hunter, this year's vice-president,
was the sole nominee for the vicepresidency, and is therefore sure to
be a member of the board again
next year. He was also nominated
with Jack Fulton for president.
The number of nominees for the
other positions is unusually large.
The nominations are: President,
John S. Fulton and James F.
Hunter; vice-president, J. F. Hunter; corresponding secretary, Wilmer Ray, James Easter, H. Milton
Wagner, and Frederick C. Lee;
alumni delegate, Dr. Radcliffe;
medical delegate, Gilbert Horrax,
Eveleth Bridgman, Harvey H.
Musser, and Hank Shaw; graduate
delegate, C. Guy Kelly, Edward 0.
Hulburt, Seymour S. Merfick,
Richard S. McCabe, and E. C. Stollenwerck ; senior delegates (two),
Donald K. Belt, William Gail, G.
Lauts Schmeisser, Hyland P. Stewart, and John S. Fulton, Jr.;
junior delegate, Wilmer Ray, C.
Leland Getz, Ernest J. Pieper, and
George M. Gillet, Jr.; sophomore
delegate, Guy Hollyday, W. Degges
Sutton, J. L. Dorsey, H. E. Catlin,
Lawson Wilkins,and Roger Howell.
John M. Holmes, the retiring
. president, was renominated, but declined on account of being graduate
manager and treasurer next year.
He has ably filled the office of
president for the last four years.

Hopkins won the final game for
the intercollegiate championship of
the United States Saturday, beating
Stevens decisively by 9 goals to 3.
A difficult game was expected, and
though it did not come, Hopkins,
nevertheless, played in form, and
demonstrated that she was clinching the championship by well-judged playing, which warrants first
position in the league.
The first half opened with a try
at Hopkins' goal, which Sutton
carried off to the side and saved.
The ball then came into Stevens'
territory to hover about her goal
for, six minutes and shot into the
net from Paulus' stick for the first
score. After the face-off, Paulus
had another try at goal, but missed
and the ball went into our territory,
where Sutton continued his excellent work of stopping tries and
carrying them out to the side. All
through the game he received the
approval of the crowds in the
stands, for his clever playing. The
rest of the half the play was around
Stevens' goal; and after repeated
tries at goal, Hulburt scored after
Gillet had brought the ball down
the field and given it to Wolfe, who
passed it to Hulburt. The third
goal was a present to Hopkins,
Bartlet, of Stevens, pushing the ball
into his own net.
In the second half, Hopkins
showed her real worth and the extent to which the coaches had developed the attack. The men played an open game in Stevens' territory most of the time, seldom
letting the ball get out .of their
hands, though often enough to permit Stevens to score three times.
Stone, of Stevens, was prominent
at these times when he carried the
play from his defense down to the
attack and dangerously near our
goal. The prettiest play of. the
game came near the end of the
second half. Hopkins got hold of
the ball and passed it to Wolfe near
the net, who passed, in turn across
to Hulburt, who sent the ball to
Gail. By a backward stroke he
landed it in the net over the goalkeeper's shoulders.

Saturday, for the first time in
three years, Hopkins defeated the
University of Virginia in the annual
track and field meet, held at Homewood, by 62 3 points to 41 y3.
There were no records broken, but
each event was exciting, and the
crowd was on its feet during most
of them. Although the score would
lead one to think that Hopkins had
an easy time in defeating the visitors, the reverse is the case. There
were only two events in which the
visitors did not place, and one of
these was offset by one event-the
880-yard run-in which Hopkins
did not place.
Horrax, of the Medical School,
scored the largest number of points.
By 'Winning first in the 120-yard
low hurdles, the running broad
jump, and the pole vault, and by
tying for first in the running highjump he scored I73/3 points for
Hopkins.
Freddie Lee won both the mile
and two-mile runs, in two races,
both of whose finishes brought the
crowd to its feet. The outcome of
the two-mile run was doubtful up
to the last lap, when Freddie
showed that the Virginian, who
had been keeping right up with
him, could not pass him.

Tennis Tournament.

The tennis courts at Homewood
have been put in condition for college tournament, which will begin
on Monday, May 22. There will
be an entrance fee of fifty cents to
cover the cost of the prizes for the
winners of the singles, doubles, and
consolations. Any member of the
tennis committee-Clary, Belt, or
Merrick-will receive the entrance
fees before the 22nd.
All matches will be the best two
out of three, except the finals, which
will be the best three out of five.
Huck, of the College, and Post, of
the Medical School, met last year
in the finals, which Post won after
a hard i:truggle.

of the branches of those small trees,
reach below the surface of the
water and tangled together they
present an almost impenetrable
barrier to one wishing to visit the
center of an island. Their submerged parts swarm with tropical
marine life.
The beauty of some of the
natural waterways among these
islands is simply superb. The
writer of this account has in his
possession some kodak photos of
these islands and the points of interest to a biologist around Montego Bay and will be glad to show
them to any one wishing to see
them.
Another point of interest to us
and which came in for its full
share of the attention and study of
the expedition is the Salt Pond,
which is just west of the town.
This pond is really a former mouth
of Montego River, which has
changed its course and its old outlet has become blocked with sand,
so that the pond is now quite a few
yards from the normal high-water
mark. The salinity of the water of
this pond is due to the fact that in
times of severe storm the waves
dash clear over the intervening sand
into the pond. In the rainy season,
too, when the Montego River
sometimes overflows its banks, some
of this water flows into it. This
combination of circumstances makes
the pond a very interesting subject
for study. An investigation was
made of its ecology as well as a
record of its temperature and
salinity at various points, and a
map Was made of it and of the
Bogue Islands.
AUSTIN R. MIDDLEToN.

The last article descriptive of the
Hopkins Biological Expedition to
Jamaica last summer concluded the
account of our experiences in the
eastern end of the island, and in the
present paper we wish to write of
our stay at Montego Bay, on the
northwestern coast, where the Johns
Hopkins University Zoological Laboratory was located.
Montego Bay proved to be an
ideally located place for our purposes; the laboratory was perhaps
half a mile north of the town and
only a few yards from the water's
edge, along which runs the public
highway. The buildings were surrounded by yards, which joined
those of the residence of Mr.
Doubleday, the United States Consul to Montego Bay, whose little
private wharf was very kindly
placed at our disposal and afforded
us a most convenient place for
docking the skiff that the University had sent down and Professor
Andrews' gasoline launch.
It would be impossible to give
a detailed or diary-like account of
the ten weeks that we spent at
Montego Bay, so we will content
ourselves with trying to describe
a few of the very many delightful
excursions that were made there.
As the train approaches Montego
Bay it suddenly emerges from a
tunnel high on the mountain side
and then there is seen spread out
below, a mile or so away, the little
town skirting the mountain-circled

• Silvester pitched Hopkins to victory against the nine of Delaware
College, at Newark, Del., last Saturday, 5 to I. The Black and Blue
twirler was in rare form, and allowed only one hit. He was excellently supported by his team-mates.
Coach Shaw has made a wonderful difference in the Hopkins team
during the short time he has had
charge of it. The players not only
fielded well, but they also showed
up well at the bat, making I I hitstwo of which were bingles.
Hopkins started scoring in the
second inning. Taylor made a wild
throw of Wilson's grounder, followed by a two bagger by Pieper
and a single by Dors2y, which netNI two runs.
Harvey scored the only run for
Delaware in the fifth session. He
was given a pass, stole second,
went to third on an error and
scored on an infield out.
Hopkins tallied again in the
eighth period after two hands were
out. Pieper, Disney and Dorsey
singled in succession and Pieper
crossed the plate.
The last two runs were made
in the ninth inning. Silvester
opened with a single. Smith followed with a two bagger. Silvester scored on a passed ball and
Smith went to third. He scored on
Newman's timely single.

The first interscholastic meet
held by Hopkins took place Saturday morning and afternoon, at
Homewood. The heats of the dashes
and the field events were held in
the morning. The firials in the
dashes, and the 440, 88o, and mile
runs were held in the afternoon,
before the meet with Virginia.
The feature of the meet was the
pole-vaulting of Curtis, of Tome.
He broke the South Atlantic A. A.
U. record for the scholastic polevault by two inches, and his own
school record by ten and one-half
inches.
The meet, on the whole, was an
unqualified success.

THE NEWS ',ETTER
VOL. XV, No. 28.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 15, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

CHANGE IN MEDICAL SCHOOL

ATHLETIC BOARD NOMINATIONS

LACROSSE CHAMPIONSHIP

VIRGINIA OUTCLASSED

Department Heads Will Be Paid Larger
Salaries and Will Give Up
Private Practices.

Annual Meeting of General Athletic
Association Held Last Monday in
Hopkins Hall-Election Today.

A Remarkable Lacrosse Season Closes
Without a Defeat for Black and
Blue -Hopkins 9, Stevens 3.

The Hopkins Track and Field Men Exceed Most Sanguine ExpectationsHopkins 62 1-3, Virginia 41 2-3.

For the past week there has
been a great •deal of discussion in
the newspapers and elsewhere of
the change which it is proposed to
make in the policy of permitting
professors at the Medical School to
devote a large amount of their time
to their private practices. By the
new method, larger salaries will be
paid and the doctors will be permited to have private surgical and medical practice only at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The change has been agitated
ever since Dr.J.Whitridge Williams
received the deanship in January,
and it is well known that when Dr.
Howell resigned and Dr. Williams
was elected, there was an • understanding that the latter should be
free to agitate for the change, which
he favors very much. So far, nothing definite has been done, but Dr.
Williams has stated that the discussions in the Medical Faculty
have shown that the professors
unanimously favor the plan and that
a recommendation urging its adoption will probably be made to the
board of trustees.
Dr., Williams estimates that only
five or six department heads will
be affected at first, and then the
severance will be made to apply to
the men directly under them. He
does not think that the change will
be followed by any, resignations,
as he says that it will be inaugurated only if it is thought best for
Hopkins and that all of the professors have the welfare of the institution at heart and are willing to do
everything in their power to increase its efficiency.
What part Dr. Abraham Flexner
had in proposing the change has
also been much discussed. During
February, he was in Baltimore for
over a week, attending, while he
was here, the Commemoration exercises and discussing medical education with his professorial frier0s.
While he was here, also, the first
public announcement of the change
was made at the alumni dinner,
February 22, when Dr. Williams
acted as toastmaster. It was stated
Saturday, however, that although
Dr. Flexner fully approves of the
plan, it was agitated at Hopkins
before he ever came down here, and
that his advocacy is that of a private individual and not as the
head of the Medical Department
of the Carnegie Fund for the Advancement of Teaching. It is not
believed that the advocacy of Dr.
Flexner will. cause Mr. Carnegie
to loosen up for the money.

In accordance with the constitution of the Johns Hopkins Athletic
Association, the annual meeting for
the nominations of the officers and
delegates to the Board of Governors
of the General Athletic Association
was held last Monday in Hopkins
Hall. The election will be held
today at 5 P. M. in the same place.
Dr. Radcliffe, whose term as
alumni delegate has expired, was
unanimously renominated. Jimmie
Hunter, this year's vice-president,
was the sole nominee for the vicepresidency, and is therefore sure to
be a member of the board again
next year. He was also nominated
with Jack Fulton for president.
The number of nominees for the
other positions is unusually large.
The nominations are: President,
John S. Fulton and James F.
Hunter; vice-president, J. F. Hunter; corresponding secretary, Wilmer Ray, James Easter, H. Milton
Wagner, and Frederick C. Lee;
alumni delegate, Dr. Radcliffe;
medical delegate, Gilbert Horrax,
Eveleth Bridgman, Harvey H.
Musser, and Hank Shaw; graduate
delegate, C. Guy Kelly, Edward 0.
Hulburt, Seymour S. Merfick,
Richard S. McCabe, and E. C. Stollenwerck ; senior delegates (two),
Donald K. Belt, William Gail, G.
Lauts Schmeisser, Hyland P. Stewart, and John S. Fulton, Jr.;
junior delegate, Wilmer Ray, C.
Leland Getz, Ernest J. Pieper, and
George M. Gillet, Jr.; sophomore
delegate, Guy Hollyday, W. Degges
Sutton, J. L. Dorsey, H. E. Catlin,
Lawson Wilkins,and Roger Howell.
John M. Holmes, the retiring
. president, was renominated, but declined on account of being graduate
manager and treasurer next year.
He has ably filled the office of
president for the last four years.

Hopkins won the final game for
the intercollegiate championship of
the United States Saturday, beating
Stevens decisively by 9 goals to 3.
A difficult game was expected, and
though it did not come, Hopkins,
nevertheless, played in form, and
demonstrated that she was clinching the championship by well-judged playing, which warrants first
position in the league.
The first half opened with a try
at Hopkins' goal, which Sutton
carried off to the side and saved.
The ball then came into Stevens'
territory to hover about her goal
for, six minutes and shot into the
net from Paulus' stick for the first
score. After the face-off, Paulus
had another try at goal, but missed
and the ball went into our territory,
where Sutton continued his excellent work of stopping tries and
carrying them out to the side. All
through the game he received the
approval of the crowds in the
stands, for his clever playing. The
rest of the half the play was around
Stevens' goal; and after repeated
tries at goal, Hulburt scored after
Gillet had brought the ball down
the field and given it to Wolfe, who
passed it to Hulburt. The third
goal was a present to Hopkins,
Bartlet, of Stevens, pushing the ball
into his own net.
In the second half, Hopkins
showed her real worth and the extent to which the coaches had developed the attack. The men played an open game in Stevens' territory most of the time, seldom
letting the ball get out .of their
hands, though often enough to permit Stevens to score three times.
Stone, of Stevens, was prominent
at these times when he carried the
play from his defense down to the
attack and dangerously near our
goal. The prettiest play of. the
game came near the end of the
second half. Hopkins got hold of
the ball and passed it to Wolfe near
the net, who passed, in turn across
to Hulburt, who sent the ball to
Gail. By a backward stroke he
landed it in the net over the goalkeeper's shoulders.

Saturday, for the first time in
three years, Hopkins defeated the
University of Virginia in the annual
track and field meet, held at Homewood, by 62 3 points to 41 y3.
There were no records broken, but
each event was exciting, and the
crowd was on its feet during most
of them. Although the score would
lead one to think that Hopkins had
an easy time in defeating the visitors, the reverse is the case. There
were only two events in which the
visitors did not place, and one of
these was offset by one event-the
880-yard run-in which Hopkins
did not place.
Horrax, of the Medical School,
scored the largest number of points.
By 'Winning first in the 120-yard
low hurdles, the running broad
jump, and the pole vault, and by
tying for first in the running highjump he scored I73/3 points for
Hopkins.
Freddie Lee won both the mile
and two-mile runs, in two races,
both of whose finishes brought the
crowd to its feet. The outcome of
the two-mile run was doubtful up
to the last lap, when Freddie
showed that the Virginian, who
had been keeping right up with
him, could not pass him.

Tennis Tournament.

The tennis courts at Homewood
have been put in condition for college tournament, which will begin
on Monday, May 22. There will
be an entrance fee of fifty cents to
cover the cost of the prizes for the
winners of the singles, doubles, and
consolations. Any member of the
tennis committee-Clary, Belt, or
Merrick-will receive the entrance
fees before the 22nd.
All matches will be the best two
out of three, except the finals, which
will be the best three out of five.
Huck, of the College, and Post, of
the Medical School, met last year
in the finals, which Post won after
a hard i:truggle.

of the branches of those small trees,
reach below the surface of the
water and tangled together they
present an almost impenetrable
barrier to one wishing to visit the
center of an island. Their submerged parts swarm with tropical
marine life.
The beauty of some of the
natural waterways among these
islands is simply superb. The
writer of this account has in his
possession some kodak photos of
these islands and the points of interest to a biologist around Montego Bay and will be glad to show
them to any one wishing to see
them.
Another point of interest to us
and which came in for its full
share of the attention and study of
the expedition is the Salt Pond,
which is just west of the town.
This pond is really a former mouth
of Montego River, which has
changed its course and its old outlet has become blocked with sand,
so that the pond is now quite a few
yards from the normal high-water
mark. The salinity of the water of
this pond is due to the fact that in
times of severe storm the waves
dash clear over the intervening sand
into the pond. In the rainy season,
too, when the Montego River
sometimes overflows its banks, some
of this water flows into it. This
combination of circumstances makes
the pond a very interesting subject
for study. An investigation was
made of its ecology as well as a
record of its temperature and
salinity at various points, and a
map Was made of it and of the
Bogue Islands.
AUSTIN R. MIDDLEToN.

The last article descriptive of the
Hopkins Biological Expedition to
Jamaica last summer concluded the
account of our experiences in the
eastern end of the island, and in the
present paper we wish to write of
our stay at Montego Bay, on the
northwestern coast, where the Johns
Hopkins University Zoological Laboratory was located.
Montego Bay proved to be an
ideally located place for our purposes; the laboratory was perhaps
half a mile north of the town and
only a few yards from the water's
edge, along which runs the public
highway. The buildings were surrounded by yards, which joined
those of the residence of Mr.
Doubleday, the United States Consul to Montego Bay, whose little
private wharf was very kindly
placed at our disposal and afforded
us a most convenient place for
docking the skiff that the University had sent down and Professor
Andrews' gasoline launch.
It would be impossible to give
a detailed or diary-like account of
the ten weeks that we spent at
Montego Bay, so we will content
ourselves with trying to describe
a few of the very many delightful
excursions that were made there.

Bay it suddenly emerges from a
tunnel high on the mountain side
and then there is seen spread out
below, a mile or so away, the little
town skirting the mountain-circled

ALUMNI NOTES
F. M. Rogers, Ph. D. '07, now
has a position as chemist with the
Standard Oil Company at Whiting,
Indiana.
George T. Tyler, Jr., M. D. '04,
is a United States Army surgeon.
Frank G. Porter, A. B. '04 and
M. D. '09, is practicing medicine in
Montclair, N. J.
Campbell E. Waters, A. B. '95
and Ph. D. '99, has a position as
chemist in the Bureau of Standards
at Washington, D. C.
Charles H. Brough, Ph. D. '98,
formerly a University fellow, is now
professor of economics and sociology at the University of Arkansas,
Fayetteville, Ark.
Robert I. Todd, proficient in electricity, '93, is now president of the
Indianapolis Traction Company.
Arthur W. Meyer, M. D. '05, is
professor of human anatomy at Leland Stanford University.
Clarence A. Neal, A. B. '04, has
a position in the Department of
Agriculture at Washington, D. C.
Andrew E. Lee, A. B. Stanford
'02 and M. D. Johns Hopkins 'o6, is
a surgeon at the United States
Naval Hospital, Canacao, P. I.
Charles M. Stearns, A. B., '98,
has left Harvard University and
is now the English master at the
Tome School..

• Silvester pitched Hopkins to victory against the nine of Delaware
College, at Newark, Del., last Saturday, 5 to I. The Black and Blue
twirler was in rare form, and allowed only one hit. He was excellently supported by his team-mates.
Coach Shaw has made a wonderful difference in the Hopkins team
during the short time he has had
charge of it. The players not only
fielded well, but they also showed
up well at the bat, making I I hitstwo of which were bingles.
Hopkins started scoring in the
second inning. Taylor made a wild
throw of Wilson's grounder, followed by a two bagger by Pieper
and a single by Dors2y, which netNI two runs.
Harvey scored the only run for
Delaware in the fifth session. He
was given a pass, stole second,
went to third on an error and
scored on an infield out.
Hopkins tallied again in the
eighth period after two hands were
out. Pieper, Disney and Dorsey
singled in succession and Pieper
crossed the plate.
The last two runs were made
in the ninth inning. Silvester
opened with a single. Smith followed with a two bagger. Silvester scored on a passed ball and
Smith went to third. He scored on
Newman's timely single.
Summary:
JOHNS HOPKINS.

First Interscholastic Meet.
Headquarters for the J. H. U. Seal Pins

The first interscholastic meet
held by Hopkins took place Saturday morning and afternoon, at
Homewood. The heats of the dashes
and the field events were held in
the morning. The firials in the
dashes, and the 440, 88o, and mile
runs were held in the afternoon,
before the meet with Virginia.
The feature of the meet was the
pole-vaulting of Curtis, of Tome.
He broke the South Atlantic A. A.
U. record for the scholastic polevault by two inches, and his own
school record by ten and one-half
inches.
The meet, on the whole, was an
unqualified success.
